element_texts.text:
greeting card
"... and a Partridge in a Pear Tree"
Best wishes for Christmas and the New Year
BEATRICE and HARRY MOORE
Your card was exciting, as always, & we appreciate the little tracts which help to keep us on the straight & narrow.  didn't know you were in London, Jack, or I'd have looked you up when I was there last May; there's a faint chance I'll be there again next May.  I can usually be found through ? Richard Rees, 16 Burnsall, SW ?.
Good Yule!
Harry (& Beatrice)

pencil in top margin  Flossie
Chicago, Ill
Dec 27, 69
Dear Gladys & Jack: -

  We wish you and family, a very happy "New Year"  May God Bless all of you.
   Whenever you do get to Chicago, call us and please come by.
   I just can not find that December magazine.  Have tryed [sic] many places.  Some say they do not have it any more.  So please send me the publisher's name and address, so I can write, and have them send me a copy.  Thanks in advance.

2
Carmen and Marin are well, also Roland and Jean.   Roland is going to Jamaica, over the New Year weekend.

   Matt and family are well, altho he and his wife are separated
   Sammy (Carmen's Son) is teaching school in Jamesville Wisconsin.
   Lil Armstrong is fine.  Well now I have told you some of the news, of your old friend's.  [sic]

Sincerely Flossie
P.S.  My Brother is well, his son Arch was by Christmas, he is not married

[in pencil in top margin]   Moore, Flossie
letterhead   From the desk of FLOSSIE MOORE
11-18-81
Hi Folks:

   Hope you both are well.  We are OK Thank God  Sammy still does some work, each day
   This is Carmen's writing on the back of this picture thought you would like to have it   Sammy called me last week saying he is going to have us over to dinner after the holidays.  Marvin is fine gets all around.  Zev was in Chicago last week he

called, he calls me from Los Angeles or where every [sic] he is double underline:  every year on Millards birthday  I think I told you he married and now has a little girl about five years old.

   And I see Matt and talk to him very often.  He has married again and does not drink anything for underlined:  years now.  All his family are O.K.  We all get together once in a while.  Love to both of you.  Flossie & Sammy

[in pencil in top margin]   Moore, Flossie  [26 Jan 1981]
letterhead   From the desk of FLOSSIE MOORE
Dear Jack:

   Hope you and Gladys are well.  Sammy and I are O.K.  He still works (for his self) every day.
    Matt Noriega got married again.
    Arch, Brother's son is talking about getting married, he is 48 yrs old and has never been married.
    With much love to both of you, as ever  Flossie  (over)
The Mass at my church was so very beautiful, for Brother.

[in pencil in top margin]   Moore, Flossie
letterhead   Mrs. Flossie Moore   253 West 60th Street   Chicago, Illinois  60621
Jan 5, 79
Dear Jack:

    I know you are surprised to hear from me, and I pray you and family are well, and enjoyed the Holiday's. [sic]  I am fine for an old lady of 85.  God has been so good to both of us.  Sammy works every day.  We see Matt and his family every once in awhile.  I am sure you know Carmen and Hope both passed some time ago.
   Enclosed there is a copy of the letter, our Lawyer sent us.  So do hope you can help with these books.  As you know I did not get

2
anything.

   "God Bless You" and family.  As ever your friend.   Flossie

P.S.  Frederica Westbrooke is my Daughter

   Mr Walter Roth, is our Lawyer.

in pencil in top margin  Mori, Chiye
Christmas card   Merry Christmas
December 16, 1943
Dear Jack -

   Christmas rolls around again, bourgeois holiday that it is, but it has some compensations.  For instance, it stirs me into getting a few notes out thanking my friends for the nice things they've done for me during the past year.  It's helped me over the rough spots and helped me to brave the cold cruel world.
   I suppose you still hold the fort at Consolidated Publisher's [sic] and teach occasionally at Lincoln School.  My drafting course keeps me so occupied that I don't even get around to Washington Blvd. for an occasional lecture.  I'm working as a floral designer at a west side shop and between 50 to 60 hours of work a week, 15 hours of school I find my time

rigidly rationed.  It became so bad that I had to play possum to get my holiday correspondence out.  The current flu epidemic gave me a good excuse.  Hope you haven't been victimized yet.

   By the way, how is your play coming along.   Let me know when its [sic] produced so that I can throw appropriate brick bats.
   Since custom dictates a merry Christmas I'll go the whole hog and wish you an extra special one with all the fancy trimmings.

As ever,
Chiye Mori

in pencil in top margin    Morris, Dan
postcard "THE GREAT WHITE WAY"  Time Square - The Heart of New York's Entertainment
postmark  NEW YORK, NY  100   PM   25 AUG 1985    stamp  F. A. Bartholdi, Statue of Liberty Sculptor  USA 22
POST CARD
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO  65270
Sat. nite, Aug. 24, 1985
Dear Jack:

  Couldn't find any dirty postcards for you at Times Square.  They've moved the porn a few blocks off the Great White Way.
  Had a good two-day visit with Abe Megil, last editor of New Masses.  He thought highly of you, but remembered Lewis as a doggeral [sic]  poet.
  Slept in a campground last night; staying with a Democratic Socialists of America member in Brooklyn tonight.

More anonce.
Take care, Dan Morris

postcard  CANDLEWOOD THEATRE  Routes 37 & 39  New Fairfield, Connecticut
postmark  WATERBURY, CT 067  21 AUG 1985     postage stamp  Sinclair Lewis   USA 14
pencil in top margin  Morris, Dan
JACK CONROY
701 FISK
Moberly, MO  65270
Wed, Aug. 21, 1985  Danbury, Conn
Dear Jack:
Earlier card got lost.  I'll send it when I find it.

  Good talks with Dorothy West ( underlined:  the Living is Easy ) on Martha's Vineyard and with Malcom Cowley.  Cowley didn't want to do my ?circle with line? sorts, tho.
  Spent a day at ms. collection at Brown & 1½ days at ms. collection at Yale (not much time in Beinecke Library there.)  Found letter Com crossed out:  Dwight Kenneth Rexroth to Dwight MacDonald saying he had rediscovered you in early '50s in Chicago after Walter Rideout's book came out.  Cowley heard you charmed them at Yaddo.  Take care, DAN MORRIS

postcard with printed stamp  George Wythe Patriot  USA 14

Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO

pencil in right margin  Morris, Dan
Monday, Aug. 19, 1985
Providence, R.I.
Brown University
Dear Jack:

 Leaving Brown after a week and heading toward Sherman, Connecticut this afternoon to see Malcolm Cowley. 
 Spent a day and a half in Columbus with Joseph Vogel; spent Saturday afternoon on Martha's Vineyard with Dorothy West.
 Heading today for second, longer visit to Beinecke Library to look at more correspondence.   Found good underlined:  Anvil, Rebel Poet letters here and will see more at Yale.  Been set up for New York with some old party people.
  In Providence my host, Harry Williams, who visited you last month, set me up with George Bass, Langston Hughes' longtime personal secretary, who ?round symbol with line? sorted as Hughes.  I'll fill you in in a few weeks.  Take care.  Dan Morris

humorous greeting card   THIS A'INT WIND!  EXCUSE MY HURRY  File:Man running toward outhouse
pencil in top margin  Morris, Dan
You were around for two Haley's Comets, so why not two Watergates?
Reagan's getting into it deeper every day!  It smells, and I love it.
Keep the home fires burning in Athens of the Prairie.

pencil in top margin  Morris, Dan
postcard BUSY CABLE CARS climb the steep, terraced Powell Street Hill at twilight time.  San Francisco, California
postmark  OAKLAND CA 946  PM 25 MAR 1988     postage stamp  Sinclair Lewis  USA 14
JACK CONROY, patient
Columbia House Health Care
Towne Drive
Columbia, MO  65202
Friday, March 25, 1988
Dear Jack:
Two friends and I are having a Bukowski-esque time in Frisco.  Car trouble, flea bag hotels, the whole bit.
Got to City Lights Books, though.  Cheap dinner in Chinatown, etc.  What a great city!  Public transport is cheap, and convenient, too.  Staying near Berkeley and prowling the campus and bookstores there.  Already in one Honduras demonstration.  Hope you keep improving.  Hang in there.  DAN MORRIS

letterhead  Central Methodist College  The Missouri Methodist College of Liberal Arts   RALPH L. WOODWARD, President   FAYETTE, MISSOURI   Division of Social Sciences
November 24, 1968
Mr. Jack Conroy
Moberly, Missouri
Dear Mr. Conroy:

    I want to thank you for your exceptionally well written and perceptive review of underlined:  The American Serfs ...., which appeared in the Kansas City paper.  I  have brought both to the attention of my students.
   I would like to purchase a copy of your novel underlined:  The Disinherited .  Could you send me the address of the publisher?
   I know, from my own writing, that you are extremely busy with your opus, but would you consider speaking to some of my classes?  Time and place would be entirely up to you.
   Please consider and let me know.  I would certainly like to meet and talk with  you.

Yours truly,
Hobart L. Morris 
History Department

letterhead  Central Methodist College  The Missouri Methodist College of Liberal Arts   RALPH L. WOODWARD, President   FAYETTE, MISSOURI   Division of Social Sciences
November  29, 1968
Dear Mr. Conroy:

    Thank  you sincerely for your letter.   I have sent away (to Larry Goldberg) for copies of two of your works.  I look forward with anticipation to reading them.
    Thank you for the autographed copy of "Home to Moberly".  It is a fascinating recollection of events and people of the past.
    I am sure we can make arrangements after the 1st of the year.  I appreciate your kind offer very much.  (If you were to make a speech what is your fee?)
    I hope to be able to talk with  you in the near future.
    Thank you for your cooperation.

Yours truly,
Hobart Morris
History Department

in pencil in top margin  Morris, Hobart
letterhead    seal CENTRAL METHODIST COLLEGE   1854  FAYETTE, MISSOURI

CENTRAL METHODIST COLLEGE    FAYETTE, MISSOURI  65248    DIVISION OF SOCIAL SCIENCES

October 30, 1976
Dear Mr. Conroy:

   I am enclosing a beautiful article by Colman McCarthy on your friend Arno Bontemps.  I am a fan of many years standing!   Your recent book review of Wood Guthrie was outstanding and I brought it to the attention of my students.  We do miss Woody, don't we!
   I am also taking the liberty of enclosing two additional articles for your interest.
   Kindest personal regards.

Sincerely,
Prof. Hobart Morris
You do wonder just underlined: who the gov't represents?
Sanity is where you find it!

Mr. Conroy
Art Center
3831 Michigan
Sunday 4/13
4 - 7
Sorry you didn't receive the announcement.
Margaret Morris

in pencil in top margin  Edwa Moser
7164 Northmoor
June 20, 1945
Dear Jack,

   Congratulations on underlined:  They Seek !   I had already cut this bit from "The New Yorker".   I haven't got your book yet, but I shall buy myself one (it's time, every so often,  to give oneself a present) and I'll recommend it to all and sundry.
   I will be darned about Fannie & Geo. Wash. Carver!  I hope her novel rings a bell better than the last one did.  Her negroes especially.
   I'd love to come to the Conference unless Kev gets leave at that

time.  He may.  His last before going to the Pacific.  You know how it is.

    I haven't heard anything of W.D. and the movies.  Or of my last opus, which has been at D.S.&P's for 2 weeks.  Hopes --
    Why not get Winkler to do your review?  I think he is an excellent critic, perceptive and original.  He does reviews for the P-D since he is at HSD, you know.
    I'm greatly astonished at the State School Superintendent, & have sent for a booklet instanter.
    Tell me, underlined:  did you come to St. L. in April?   I'll never speak to you again if you did come, without letting me know.  After all, I am the only person who ever

7064 Northmoor
St. Louis 5, Mo.
Dear Jack,

  I was so glad to have your letter underlined:  and the enclosures!   I immediately sent them on to Kev, who as a fiendish First Class-man at the Coast Guard Academy, has made numerous little Swabs memorize them & sing him to sleep with them.  "When I forfeit manhood's claim", indeed!
  I am sure my (if ever) Hollywood ventures will be safe, for the deal is handled by the Duell, Sloan & Pease agent.  No news yet.

I've never got very thrilled about children's books, somehow.
   I'm awfully glad to hear how well you are doing.
   DO, if you come to St. Louis, let me know!   If you come after April 7th, I'll have a party for you.  Not before:  my daughter insists on Quiet to study for College Board Exams.  How much I'd like to see you again!
   I hope I can do better on writers' shindigs this year.  If it comes off, however, where my Kev is home for the last time for two years, you can bet what I'll do!
   Don't hope for too much about your book being out on time!  I'll certainly get one when it

2
appears and boost all I can.   What on earth underlined: is a "Sooner Hound"?

    Tell me more about Bontemps.  What color is he?  Not that it particularly matters -- I wonder, by the way, what became of Lomask.
    I'm so glad of T. Williams' success.   He's had such a frightful time with his eyes.
    From its present state, I think my new book will be finished next month -- hope springs eternal -- ah me!  don't it tho'?

Best wishes,
Edwa

March 1st, 1946
Dear Jack,

  Just a note to apologize for not having answered your swell and speedy letter.  Thing is the situation ironed itself out and I've had my nose pressed to manuscript paper ever since I wrote to you.  However the book is finished now and I'm returning to Chicago and will call you up almost immediately to give you the dope.  I met and had lunch with Arna and saw underlined:  St. Louis Woman in rehearsal.  It looked

2.
damn good to me.  I haven't had a chance to look Jack Wilgus up but he surely sounds like a real guy!  thanks for sending his letter on to me -- I'll return it to you when I see you.  Incidentally I saw a copy of the first issue of underlined: The Anvil in a bookstore window -- one dollar.  Started to buy it for you.  Decided to definitely do so the next day.  Went back.  It had been sold.

3

  I've been thinking about your anthology and have a couple ideas which I'll pass on to you when I see you.  Excuse the pencil -- I have no fountain pen and Macmillans has picked up the typewriter I was using.   Well ---  I'll see you soon.

As ever,
Willard

postcard  File:Row of filled champagne glasses    HAPPY NEW YEAR   ENOUGH TO LAST THROUGHOUT the whole year
Jack, I wanted to get to see  you before headin' west but things were so hectic I didn't get a chance.  Hope your novel is coming along!    Will   Box  106  Route 2  Battle Ground, Washington
Willard and Morry

postcard]

Will

Jack - I'll meet you and Nelson at the Peek-a-Boo (next to the Victory on North Clark) whenever  you can make it.
Willard

greeting card with photograph of man standing, woman seated with lute
in pencil in top margin  Muhrer, Verle  [1976?]
Dear Jack,

 We're sorry to hear about your daughter doing so poorly.
  The baby finally got here.   I had a reaction to the anesthetic so was in the hospital a few extra days but we're both home now & feeling fine.  Maybe we can get up to Moberly in the near future and show him off.  We had

inside of greeting card
the picture taken last winter & thought you'd enjoy having one.

  Greetings to Gladys.

Verle & Jan
written in red ink below signature  Muhrer  '76

in pencil in top margin  Michèle

Dr Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO
65270
Greeting from the only town named "St Patrick" in the world right here in MO.  See you in the fall.
Solidarity, Verle & Michèle
Hi Jack, HOPE You're DOIN' GREAT.  Michèle

in pencil in top margin  Verle & John Henry
postcard CUSTER BATTLEFIELD NATIONAL MONUMENT  Crow Agency, Montana    Lt. Colonel George A. Custer seen here in 1865, when he wa a major general at the age of 25.  Custer designed his own uniform.  Photographed by the Civil War photographer Matthew Brady.  RC2022-Photo:  National Park Service
postmark  BABB, MT 59411  AUG 15  -PM  1986       Stamp Sinclair Lewis   USA 14

Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO
65270
USA
8/11/86
Dear Comrade Jack,

 John Henry & I are camping in Alberta, Canada, north of Glacier National Park.   Dig the Colonel's picture here, cold-eyed, steely looking, arrogant and a swaggering dandy for sure.   The little white Rambo of his day.  "Old iron ass," as his men called him, treated his dog better than them.  And old Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse, and the boys ran him down just for sport like a hunted Buffalo.  Don't let the bastards grind you down, etc.   Cheers, Verle & John Henry

in pencil in top margin  Muhrer, Verle
March 7, 1988
Dear Fellow Skeptics:

    For most of you, James (The Amazing) Randi needs no introduction.  He is simply the greatest debunker of our age and a friend of our skeptical movement worldwide.
    We are grateful the the U.S. Toy Company, Magic Division, and Philip Kline at U.S. Toy Company for brining [sic] James Randi to Kansas City.
    James Randi will be lecturing at U.S. Toy Company, behind Gates Bar-B-Que, 103rd Terrace and State Line at 2:00 p.m. on Sunday, March 13th.  tickets will be $7.00 in advance and $8.00 the day of the lecture.
    There will be a reception of Kansas City Free Thinkers and Skeptics for James Randi immediately following the licture at Gates Bar-B-Que.  The Kansas City Committee for Skeptical Inquiry will present James Randi an award.  Please bring your ticket stub.
    We hope to see you there.
    For more information please contact:  Verle Muhrer, Kansas City Committee for Skeptical Inquiry, 2658 East 7th, Kansas City, Missouri  64124 (816) 241-0162 and work:  932-7600 x797; or Philip Kline, U.S. Toy Company, Magic Division, 2008 West 103rd Terrace, Leawood, Kansas 66206  (913) 642-8247.

Very truly yours,
KC COMMITTEE FOR SKEPTICAL INQUIRY
signature Verle Muhrer
Verle Muhrer
PS.  We are giving Randi a copy of underlined: Elmer Gantry, making a tie to S. Lewis' KC connection w/ the evangelists that proliferate these parts.
signature Verle

in pencil in top margin   Muhrer, Verle  [no date]
Next Jackson Benefit House Concert:
SPARKY RUCKER AND FRIENDS

    Sparky is a black folk musician from Knoxville, TN, and is one of the best traditional style folk musicians on the professional scene today.   He does traditional black music deep in the Afro-American tradition, and has dedicated his professional life to preserving this rich, but ignored and underappreciated cultural heritage from which all modern music in America and much of the world springs.   But Sparky is not interested in  preserving a precious past, and digging lost Afro-American songs up from the cemetery of folk history for its own sake.  His sole concern is the future, and sees his music as deeply committed to a better world.  He continues to write new songs and collect and add new songs to his repitoire. [sic]    Don't miss one of the best concert performers of folk music ever.

Place:  2658 East 7th, KCMO 64126
PHONE: 816-351-9163
DATE:  Saturday Evening, March 17, 1984  (ST. PATRICK'S DAY!!!)
TIME:  Children's Concert  8:00-9:00

            Sparky Rucker        9:00-1:0 0

ADMISSION:  $3.00 PER ADULT
BENEFIT FOR JACKSON CAMPAIGN.
MAKE CHECKS OUT TO THE "JESSE JACKSON FOR PRESIDENT COMMITTEE"  (TAX DEDUCTIBLE)
[handwritten at bottom of page]]
Special attractions!
1.  "Spike Bones" world's greatest bones performer will do the children's concert at 8:00/
2.  Jessica Henderson, chairperson of "Women for Jackson" will "orate" at 11:30.
See you there.
Verle & John

postcard with stamp and postmark torn off
[[caption in Russian with multiple language translations.  English]   The Teremnoi Palace.  Golden Palata      Moscow 1967
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri  
65270
U.S.A.
Moscow, U.S.S.R torn off
Sept. 23, 1968
Dear Jack;

  This morning I had a conference with some Russian leaders.  We had an interesting discussion on Czechoslovakia.  We didn't agree but it was a lot of fun.   Here I just can't get any news.  This morning I had to read a communist paper in French to find out what is happening in the world.

Floyd Mulkey

has been trying to write the story of her girlhood in North Dakota.  I know her story would be very interesting but she is continually pressed into service activities here so she has no time for writing.
Floyd Mulkey

letterhead    MRS. HLAVAC MUNROE  117 SOUTH FOURTH STREET MOBERLY, MISSOURI  65270
Oct. 3/68
Thanks! HM
P.S.  The one of Yan's which you did not get to read was, apparently, wrenched out of youthful strife (June '68):
Young men
in bed
are frequently confused 
By cocks

   and muscles
         alive, alive O!!

With apologies for this last, if they're necessary   HM

postcard  BEAUTIFUL NORTHPORT POINT FROM THE AIR   On the tip of Leelanau County, north of Traverse City, Michigan, lies a beautiful peninsula.  Grand Traverse Bay and Lake Michigan surround the area.
postmark  NORTHPORT.  MI  49670  AUG 11  PM  1970   STAMP  6C  FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT  U.S. POSTAGE
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
circled:  711 ? Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo. 65270

AUG. 11/70
Dear Mr. & Mrs. Conroy, we made it up underlined: via Ann Arbor where I dumped 5 people, continuing with only the dog, the cat, and camping equipment for at least an army, and a year. - The Kids came up from Ann Arbor Blues Festival hale, hearty, hungry, and ?fretting? but have recovered fast. - two of my  young friends, Jennifer and Larry Dinger, will be going down to Moberly at the end of the week, and would like to call on you all while there. - He wants to get a Masters' in folklore somewhere, and needs som pointers; she's a young English teacher, former student of mine.  Thanks.
Best, Ato Munroe

letterhead    Mrs. Hlavac Munroe  4609 Orchard Lane   Columbia, Missouri 65201
December 14, 1973
Dear Mrs. Conroy and Jack,

  just a few lines to wish you a peaceful Christmas and both of you & all the rest of us a damn' well 4 underlines: better better new year than we've had.   I should love to stop in to see you all if I get to Moberly during the holidays - if for no other reason than to hear you,

Jack, comment on the Watergate.  I see that your friend, prof. Febre, published his Wright book - I'll have to get it when the new year rolls around (read: paycheck...).

   Keep well, drop me a line sometime.  By the way, that nice Herb Stappenbeck got a terminal contract...he's leaving at the end of the year.  You'd like him, I know.
   So, until I see you again ... love,

Ata Munroe

holiday card:  AND BEST WISHES FOR HAPPINESS THROUGHOUT THE NEW YEAR
117 S. 4th, Moberly, Mo. 65270
December 15, 1974
Dear Jack and Mrs. Conroy,

  I hope (the Christmas mail service being what it sometimes can be) this reaches you by Christmas.  I want to wish you all that you wish the season to bring you (and I don't mean the usual chillblains, runny noses, and side walk shoveling).
   I'v been teaching - since September - at the Mission Training Center for Men; it and the MVC are institutions of the same color (red brick) and even some of the same spirit.  One of these days, Jack, you might want to volunteer to come visit my classes & talk about some of your experiences & might say a word or two about Arna Bontemps.  I loaned one of the men his underlined:  Black Thunder.  I even took your name in vain when I made the remark that you were interested in & involved with black american literature way before I'd became crossed out: generally underlined:  the thing to do;  however,  if anyone even heard it, he'd probably have considered it a racist remark. -
   Do have a good Christmas.

Ata Munroe

in pencil in top margin  Munroe, Ata
letterhead  Mrs Hlavac Munroe crossed out:  1609 Orcahrd Lane  Columbia, Missouri  65201  117 S. 4th  Moberly
May 20/75    Sorry - delayed the mailing May 25 '75
Dear Jack,

    I suppose the underlined:  only thing I can say after reading the rather incredible story on the front page of the Monitor-Index is, "Congratulations; you've underlined: finally made it"
   I am not so sure that I want you to come to MTCM to talk to my classes; too precious few among my students know anything about literature, and many most certainly don't underlined: want to hear an unbiased view of, let's say, the Harlem Renaissance.  To be more accurate:  they're not yet ready for an unbiased view or for listening to one.

I'll see  you one of these days.
Best,
Ata Munroe
P.S. Please say hello to Mrs. Conroy for me.

post card   postmark  U.S. POSTAL SERVICE, M 496   AUG 25 1975  PM     stamp  We hold these Truths... Th. Jefferson  UNITED STATES 10c
Address
Mr & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo. 65270
Box 36A, Rt 1, Northport ?  Aug  23/75
Dear Gladys & Jack,

   I'm taking a well-deserved 4 wks on our beach near Northport, keeping a good supply of bks & beer handy, swimming, walking, & protecting myself (last day or two ) from the elements.
   This is a little town that used to be perfect & just recently has been "discovered" - i.e., has become hopeless, plus all kinds of other nasty attendant circumstances.  But I am 4-5 miles away from town so what do I care.   Will be back after Labor Day & hope to call on you soon after getting back.

Best, as ever, Ata Munroe

in pencil in top margin  Munroe, Ata
January 11/76.  Pardon me - [77]
Dear Jack,

    I have no idea what if anything will come of your visit to and lecture(s) at MTCM.  I requested it.  The response was if I do this and that, then we'll "let you" bring in Mr. Conroy.
    So, I'll probably (and regretfully) say fuck it ("fornicate it" doesn't sound good in this context) for the time being.  The psychological weapon is, of course, to make underline: me feel that I'm doing something damaging or wrong or selfish by not giving in to what is shameless blackmail.  Up to a point this works with me, past a certain point I lose enthusiasm.  So.  We'll see.
    I never wrote to your wife last crossed out:  April or later spring when I found out from you

that your daughter had died.

    I feel bad about it, too, because I know (or, rather, can imagine) how words [ underlined: real, of course] could help.   The first time death came in the close family, I wasn't even told (but I underlined: Knew ), much less consoled by words or gesture; the second time, I was literally chased out of the house, and, again, underlined:  no one but no one thought  (and, worse, underlined:  felt ) that I had suffered a dreadful, heart-and-soul-wrenching loss.  Since that time I've tried to write or say or do when someone dies. -  Do you know what I mean?  
    How is Mrs. Conroy feeling?  Well, I hope, by now.  How're your memoirs, Jack?  what chapter?  Can't you sell a course to the illustrious U. of Mo-Columbia?  Maybe even a canned one?   What's the underlined:  matter with the people there?  An M&C/ high school?   Are they courting you?   Hell, [[underlined: they] can get the underlined: Arts  Council support too, anytime they want it.  Surely Ms. Leon Bell (underlined: his. dpt./Engl/) knows that.   See you.   Best, Ata Munroe

in pencil in top margin  Murayama, Kiyohiko  Tokyo   Dec. 30, 1985
greeting card  Best Wishes for A Merry Christmas and A Happy New Year
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   Let me send you a season's greeting, which I know is rather late.  I am glad to say that my translation of youR underlined:  The Disinherited will be published on January 20.  I asked the  publishing company to send you a copy, so you will have it soon.  I would like to hear that you have got better.  

Kiyohiko Murayama
5 - 12 -4 Kitamachi,  Kokubunji  Tokyo  185  JAPAN.

in pencil in top margin  [1960s] Sheila
This has been such a busy holiday season, Mr. Conroy, that I'm just getting my Christmas cards out now.   My excuse is that I was traveling  - and I was.  Through your state, too.  I changed trains in Kansas City on my way up from the really deep south.

  I'm back in the States now for a year or so.   Took pictures of a ?crazy? animal down in C.A. that I wanted to send to you, but they didn't turn out.  It's a half-cat, half-coyote, and I couldn't find a soul who'd ever read archy and mehitabel.
  Sorry to hear about your operation.  Glad to hear about The Disinherited.
   I hope to be in Chicago in February.  If I make it, I'll look you up.  I'd like to get caught up on what's been happening in the Windy City.

Sheila

Just a side note, Mr. Conroy, to let you know I got your card from London - and such an exciting one, too.  I'll be looking for They Seek a City -  It should be helpful to me now that I'm working among the colored in Los Angeles - just outside of Watts in part of the riot area -
  It's facinating [sic] to see these people in their own habitat.  Such an infinite variety of people - Well, you know better than I.
  Your travels sound like fun.  I'd like to follow your trail.
   Glad to know Tommy still remember me.  I think of him often.
   If you ever get to Los Angeles - that's where I am now.
   Please give my regards to  your family - but Jughead and Jack must be young men by now! -
   I hope to be in Chicago next summer.
   Meantime - Merry Christmas and Happy New Year!
Sheila

(over

3830 Vinton Av.
Culver City,
California
January 17, 1967
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    Just had to drop  you a line to tell you I saw your old friend Studs Turkel on the Today show today.   When I heard he was on, I just had to watch.  He's aged - but then I haven't seen him in 15 years - and he seemed to have put on weight, but I was impressed.  And to hear about his book was interesting.  I didn't know he wrote.  I thought he was just an actor.
    Did you know Hugh Downs?   He said he was an old friend of Studs'.
    How is life and literature in Missouri?  Please keep me posted on your writings and when they are published.  Did Little Big Shorty ever come out?  and how about A Rosewood Casket?
   Greetings to Mrs. Conroy.

Sincerely,
Sheila Murphy

Christmas card   A Christmas Greeting
Just a note to say I hope everyone in the family has a happy holiday.

  And to add that I read the Time review of Don Russell's book and was thoroughly impressed.  I also came across mention, Mr. Conroy, of your book The Disinherited in a book on the New Yorker - telling about how it was one of the better books reviewed in that magazine during the Depression.   Isn't that nice to know?
    Merry Christmas and Happy New Year.

Sheila

address stamp  BENJAMIN MUSSER  107 S. Mansfield Ave.   Margate, Atlantic City, N. J.
23 Feb.
Dear Hugh Hanley:
Thanks for your letter of recent date.  But I am sorry to see you still utterly misinterpret my Dec. underlined:  Poetry World article -- or am I right in thinking your attack on this fellow Rebel Poet in her December Newsletter was influenced by Ralph Cheyney?   Ralph of course is enraged at me because I gave underlined:  C.V. to Ernest Hartsock, and I understand he has been telling everyone that I had promised to give him underlined: Contemporary Verse if I ever disposed of it.  That is not true.  I promised, underlined:  if I sold it, to let Ralph and Lucia have first refusal to purchase; there was certainly no agreement to underlined:  present it to them after I had already given them $600 for it in 1927.  But this could not interest you.
What should interest you is the fact that my underlined:  Poetry World article was not anti-Rebel at all; on the contrary I distinctly upheld radical poets of yesterday and regretted only that so many of today are untrustworthy, publicity-seekers chiefly, or who belabor the rich with their pens while nevertheless they pass the

hat among those rich to support themselves and never cease pulling wires to boost themselves into the very niches they presumably despise - even to the extent of putting a millionaire and a countess among the advisory board of underlined:  The New Contemporary Vision & Scepter  I have nothing further to say in the matter and decline to enter into a controversy.  I simply wished you to understand that my devotion to true rebel poets and to radical verse in general is unchanged, except that I have lost some confidence in belief that the general public is really influenced by rebel verse - that's what I meant by asking who would care a century hence that Harry Harrison had published a Sacco-Vanzetti anthology?  We don't even scratch the surface of public opinion in our appeals on behalf of political martyrs.
You will see by the enclosed that I am to have two new books in April.   I take it for granted you will mention these in your next Newsletter -- and it should be a glowing reference, to say the least, to counteract the bad taste exhibited by that derogatory publicity against a fellow Rebel Poet in your Dec. Newsletter.
Cordially,
Benj. Musser

in pencil in top margin  Meyers, Diane
Nov 12, 1977
Dear Dr. Conroy,

   What can the Meyers say to  you except thank you.
   Your visit with me was just incredible.   It was a real treat for all of us to meet you as a person.
    It would be a real pleasure for you to be here during dogwood season. -- We could make you the Dogwood King or something pretty famous.
    Once a king always a king but once a knight is a little much after awhile.
    No one told me to write that last line.  
    I'm finishing up a little note one of Dianne's helpers started this morning
   Hope Mrs Conroy

is doing well & that you are fit & chomping at the bit.

If we ever get to go down the Rhine we'll take you along just for the hell of it.
 Jack take care.  Keep on the stick & keep the good old brain active.  Don't get out & get pneumonia or anything.

See you
Sincerely
Dianne

in pencil in top margin  Myers, Diane  [1977]
greeting card    ... MY COMPLIMENTS TO YOUR CREATOR
Dear Jack - Happy Birthday to a really fine Human being.  We're really proud to have you for a friend.  Dianne is really proud to  have your conversation with her on tape.  We've played it a few times & it's really interesting.  When we come thru Moberly we'll bring you a birthday present.

   Guess you're keeping busy & that you are not to [sic] thrilled with the cold weather.  Hope you're [sic] wife is feeling better & that you are fit & chomping at the bit -
    Take care   Best regards  D Myers & Family

in pencil in top margin Myers, Richard   [1977]
letterhead   901 FAIRGROUND ROAD  ROLLA, MISSOURI  65401    THE MYERS CLINIC   RICHARD E. MYERS, D.O.  ROBERT S. MYERS, D.O.  GENERAL PRACTICE & OBSTETRICS
(1)
Oct 26, 77
Jack Conroy
Moberly, Mo
Dear Jack,

     My wife & I surely enjoyed visiting with you at Columbia a few wks ago when you received your award from the Mo. Library Assn.  We received the award for our daughter, Dianne because she is bedfast as a victom [sic] of Multiple Sclerosis.
    I hope you are coming down to Rolla Nov 8th to lecture.  We wish to extend you an invitation to

in pencil in top margin Myers, Richard   [1977]
letterhead   901 FAIRGROUND ROAD  ROLLA, MISSOURI  65401    THE MYERS CLINIC   RICHARD E. MYERS, D.O.  ROBERT S. MYERS, D.O.  GENERAL PRACTICE & OBSTETRICS
(3)

  We could pick you up & bring you back to Rolla or do anything to help pull this off.  It would really be good therapy for her because her mind is so active, but her body is helpless.  She was earning 17,000 per yr. in the K.C. Library when she was stricken & it's really a shame for her to have to be confined so much.
   Drop me a note if you can & will, Jack.  It would be a great thing for all of us.

Sincerely Dr. Richard E. Myers
I'd like to hear a lot of your jokes & talk about your books.  Bring some of your books down so I can buy them --

in pencil in top margin Myers
letterhead   901 FAIRGROUND ROAD  ROLLA, MISSOURI  65401    THE MYERS CLINIC   RICHARD E. MYERS, D.O.  ROBERT S. MYERS, D.O.  GENERAL PRACTICE & OBSTETRICS
Nov 26, 77
Dear Jack -

  Sure good to hear from our good friend!  You really made our day so you can see how important you are to us.
   Even if you are toooo tempted by a few bottles of good Scoth [sic] I'm going to bring you some quality stuff of the best varieties.  You don't have to drink it all at once.   Two or three good shots a day will do your old heart & soul good!   Dr.'s orders!!  You can exercise a little of the old self control & It'l help you get your spirits thru the winter a little better.

May be you'll cut loose & write a book or two after a few good belts.  Sometimes a guy needs a small stimulus.
   The trip back & forth shouldn't have been to [sic] hard on Prof Pearson.   When I was young & full of piss & Vinegar like he should be I could stay up for three days & nights & deliver several babies, make house calls, do my office work & also take care of other things that I should.  Those were the days.
   Be sure & let us know someway we can get  our hands on your books.  I started to say on your works but I realized how it would sound - Ha!
   Dianne & Betty & I really enjoyed your letter.  You really know how to use words.

letterhead   901 FAIRGROUND ROAD  ROLLA, MISSOURI  65401    THE MYERS CLINIC   RICHARD E. MYERS, D.O.  ROBERT S. MYERS, D.O.  GENERAL PRACTICE & OBSTETRICS

   Dianne says she will buy all of them.  She says she can find them all & buy a set.  She thinks you really get ripped off when you don't get more per book than you do.  
   Wish you were here for supper.   We're having cornbread & beans & big onions & hot peppers & good wine.  It's cold as a well diggers butt down here & I'm sure it's colder than a Witche's [sic] tits there.  That's the big trouble with N. Mo.  Toooo cold.  I used to run down the R.R. tracks in Kirksville on the way to school really freezing my rear off.  I didn't own a warm coat in those days, but I could run.  Now I have the warm clothes but I'm out of breath.

Dianne says she'll sell a lot of your books - Not to have people to check them out of libraries but really buy them.  She says the Sage of Moberly shouldn't provide free reading at your age etc.
   It won't be long till spring - (if you don't believe it just sign a note) & you can come down & have a real visit.  Maybe your wife will even feel like coming.   We have lots of room.
   You got a nice write up in our pretty bad Rolla paper so everything helps.  Everyone really enjoyed your talks.
    I have a million things to talk to you about, but I'll let you go for now & write a more interesting letter another day -

Kindly - The Myers Family

in pencil in top margin Myers, Richard
birthday card  way to go, birthday person...happy birthday, kid! yeah...   File:Three antlered deer
Happy birthday Jack - Hope you live forever.  Kindly Betty Myers
Dear Jack  Happy Birthday.  Hope you have many many more  Sincerely Dianne Myers 
Dear Jack You're a good man.  We need more people in this world like you.  Sincerely Dianne Myers

Dear Jack -

   Glad your [sic] feeling good to have escaped the flu.  Nearly everyone has it.  It's [sic] been keeping me busy.
   Betty & I are doing fine considering everything.  We didn't have our usual big New Years party this yr. -  Just a few old friends.  We used to have parties & have 80 to 100 guests but it was a lot of trouble & they ate & drank so much & messed up our house too much so we have given it up.   They used to stay all night & just wear us

out.  It's better to just have memories of those things.

   Delivered a set of twins Wed.  One weighed 8 lbs 10 oz & the other weight 8 lbs 6 oz - the biggest set of twin boys I ever delivered!!   That poor mother carried around 17 lbs of babies.
   Mrs Workleys ? arrived and I guess I had mentioned that before.   Take care & dont work to [sic] hard.We'll see you someday.  We are looking forward to you spending a few days with us  when the weather gets warmer.

Kindest Regards   Dr. Dick & Betty

Dear Jack -

  Good to talk to you a few minutes.  Glad you are getting along pretty good.
  We had a fine Christmas & New Year hope you did too.
   I'm feeling stronger & eating real good & getting a lot of rest 
   I feel like it's a real privelege [sic]  to know a famous world wide know[sic] author in person especially since you are such a good guy.
   Hope you get your house remodeled & that you get your autobiography written.

It costs a lot to remodel a house or to do anything at all these days.  Wish I could send you Dad's carpenter free of charge for 2 or 3 wks & some of dads boards & nails etc.  He has everything handy to build with.
   There isn't much news.  I'll catch you later when something interesting happens.
   Keep up your good work & we'll see  you someday -

Love Dianne

& it will do her a million bucks worth of good.  I also need to tape your lectures for her to hear.

   I'd take you back to Moberly myself or even to Chicago

March 22, 1966
Dear Mr. Conroy:

  I've been negligent by delaying so long to write you after your kindness in letting me know about your success in contacting ?Walynd?.  I have had two long letters from him & he took time to give some good suggestions on an article I was underlined:  trying to write on the literary dinners during the Renaissance of Negro artists in 1925 in New York.

2

  He sounded like his old enthusiastic self.
  Did I understand you to say you would be out this way this summer?  Be sure to let me know.
  Glad to hear you & Arna's book is ready for publication.   Anxious to see it.
  We have started a little Center for research - (the S. F. Negro Historical & Cultural Society).  Just in the process of gathering books, etc.

3
Give my & Glenn's regard to Mrs. Conroy & the best to you also.
Best of everything to you!
Sincerely,
Ethel Ray Nance

I must admit I have not seen the new book yet, but have ordered it.  Tried to get it after you told me about it - in London & N.Y. then got busy.  I've ordered it now.
  Send me some reviews & I'll put it in our window at the Center with the book (when it comes).   We have 4 wonderful display windows on a much travelled street.
   Be sure to look us up when you come   we'd like you to talk to a few of us - -

greeting card   Thinking of you and wishing you happiness during the holidays and throughout the new year.
Dear friends -

   I know you are keeping busy - possibly a new book?
   I have retired from the African -American Historical Society with the idea of trying to do some writing.  It's hard to keep started at it,  but I am getting materials together from diaries, etc.
   I managed to complete my story of working with Dr. DuBois but need coaching as to deleting the many "rough" spots.
   Probably I should enroll in a writing class to get some confidence (smile).
   Hope you are both well and busy.  Be sure to let us know if you come this way.

Sincerely,
Ethel Ray Nance & Glenn

12/13/67
Jack -
I'm including an article which ran in the Trib about a month ago, in case you've not seen it.  I had a large section on Chicago Little mag history, which included the New Anvil, but it was cut.  You think you could write a brief, impressionistic history of the New Anvil in Chicago (say about  2500 words) for Chicago land mag?  (I'm the new editor beginning in JAN '68)  I could pay you about $75.00.   Let me hear on this when you can.

   My son, Lee, asked me to thank you for the copy of "the Sooner Hound" which was

beautifully signed.  "Tell Mr. Jack I love it," he says.  

   Take care of yourself and let me hear from you.

Fondest regards,
Jay
P.S.  A new publishing house - dedicated to quality fiction - has started  up (you may want to send them something):  Mr. Alan Baughman   Harris-Wolfe Publishing Co.  
235 N. Main Street    Jacksonville, Ill.
